ai-mn29:0.2_0: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood
ai-mn29:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
ai-mn29:1.3_0: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:
ai-mn29:2.1_0: “Mendicants, take the case of a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking,
ai-mn29:2.2_0: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
ai-mn29:2.3_0: And I thought, “Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.”
ai-mn29:2.4_0: Once they’ve gone forth possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-mn29:2.5_0: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
ai-mn29:2.6_0: And they glorify themselves and put others down because of that:
ai-mn29:2.7_0: ‘I’m the one who possessions, honor, and popularity. These other mendicants are insignificant.’
ai-mn29:2.8_0: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity. And being negligent they live in suffering.
ai-mn29:2.9_0: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, softwood, bark, and shoots, he’d cut off the branches and leaves and depart imagining they were heartwood.
ai-mn29:2.10_0: If a person with good eyesight saw them, they’d say:
ai-mn29:2.11_0: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.
ai-mn29:2.12_0: That’s why he passed them over, cut off the shoots, and departed imagining they were heartwood.
ai-mn29:2.13_0: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he will not succeed.’
ai-mn29:2.14_0: In the same way, take a certain gentleman who goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking:
ai-mn29:2.15_0: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
ai-mn29:2.16_0: And I thought, “Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.”
ai-mn29:2.17_0: Once they’ve gone forth possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-mn29:2.18_0: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
ai-mn29:2.19_0: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
ai-mn29:2.20_0: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity. And being negligent they live in suffering.
ai-mn29:2.21_0: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the branches and leaves of the spiritual life

ai-mn29:7.1_0: And so, mendicants, this spiritual life is not lived for the sake of possessions, honor, and popularity, or for accomplishment in ethics, or for accomplishment in immersion, or for knowledge and vision.
ai-mn29:7.2_0: Rather, the goal, heartwood, and final end of the spiritual life is the unshakable freedom of heart.”

ai-mn29:7.5_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
